reviews.title: Dual carriage way bridge ...
reviews.text: It's touted as one of the key attractions in Alexandria. It's 400 m long and the only thing "iconic" about it are two towers that don't serve an obvious function. It is neither architecturally inspiring nor in any way an engineering marvel. I suspect that the cult status is has is historic: it was built to increase traffic capacity without having to demolish the private beach on the corniche. If I hadn't read about it, I wouldn't have looked at it twice.

reviews.title: BEWARE OF THE OVERPRICED BEVERAGES
reviews.text: The bridge and the beach are a sight to see but beware of the overprices beverages and kids who ask for more tips.

reviews.title: love the view
reviews.text: love the view and the fresh air, perfect spot for pictures. I recommend walking and seeing the beautiful scenery on the bridge. If you are planning to take a ride on a horse chariot please fixed the price before you take a ride otherwise they will charge you too much.

reviews.title: Nice

Beautiful historic bridge neat the beach and you could enjoy sunset at it .
So you try to visit the place surely will like it

reviews.title: Amazing view

I went there with my family for walking 
It’s amazing view weather is windy in the evening is also so beautiful  I recommended it

reviews.title: Amazing views definitely worth a visit.
reviews.text: Was staying in Alexandria and decided to pay a visit to this very famous Alexandria landmark also know as Lovers bridge.   Visited both at night and during the day.  You need to visit both sides of the bridge to appreciate it as one side overlooks the med and the other side a small cove and beach.    definitely worth the visit.

reviews.title: Great place
reviews.text:
You will be happy to stay this bridge and eat poop corn 🌽 you will be happy to stay there and take some photos 

I love Alexandria and I missed it so much

reviews.title: Amazing place
reviews.text: Amazing view for a vibrant city where you can see west and east of Alexandria. You can walk or simply use the fixed seats and sniff the fresh air

reviews.title: Amazing view

reviews.title: So nice for photos
reviews.text: So nice for photos and walking over the sea, yet you will be annoyed with beggers. Also, candy sellers passing by every now and then.

reviews.title: It’s alright.
reviews.text:
Look, I live in Alexandria, so I don’t really see the appeal of going to look at this bridge. It’s a nice bridge & all. It’s just that I’ve seen it like a million times so I don’t find it amusing.
The area surrounding the bridge is nice though, lots of nice restaurants & lounges. I still recommend it though.

reviews.title: Alexandria Landmark
reviews.text: The Stanley Bride is named for the neighborhood and bay that it was built over. The bridge was inaugurated in 2001 and has a total length of .38 miles (400 meters) with 6 spans. It was designed in an Islamic style to compliment the royal Montazah Palace which is located some distance away. Stanley Bridge is open to both pedestrian and vehicle traffic; vehicle traffic flows westbound, in one direction only. We admired as we drove across – it is a pretty Alexandria landmark!

reviews.title: Beautiful bridge in Alexandria
reviews.text: It’s a beautiful bridge. To get to it, it’s a long walk from the bibliotheca Alexandria by the corniche, or you can get a taxi or Uber. The traffic is pretty busy on the bridge, and it’s hard to cross to the other side. If you’re going to do the long walk of the corniche it’s worth seeing this landmark.

reviews.title: Perfect spot
reviews.text: I love to the view and the fresh air perfect spot for pictures and I recommend to sit at costa cafe or Pablo cafe and have your breakfast with cup of coffe in the early morning with that beautiful view i don’t recommend at all to go to the beach there its too crowded

reviews.title: Stanley Bridge

reviews.title: No lighthouse, but great Citadel and views
reviews.text: This is the location of the famous lighthouse, but all that remains of it are some stones used to build the citadel. See reviews of Fort Qaitbey on the Citadel. So if yuo're looking for the famous lighthouse, forget it. But the location is great for views of the city and sea.

reviews.title: A jewel at the Mediterranean
reviews.text:
The citadel itself - base + 2 floors - as well as the garden are excellent to appreciate the skilled results of the people who constructed this beautiful and impressive fortified castle. It’s said that part of the construction material comes from the light tower, named one of the 7 ancient wonders of the world, that was destructed by an earthquake in the 7th century.
As a cherry on the cake, the views on the city and, especially, the sea are extremely beautiful.

reviews.title: Excellent & very well maintained
reviews.text: Excellent morning sightseeing & taking this in as part of our trip,,..  this Fort is well maintained with a museum,, easy to find ,, you can see it from any point along the promenade,,.. we hire a Horse & cart for our sightseeing..  there's looky looky stall along the road as you approach,,,.. The stall holders are mild!!,,

reviews.title: Interesting building
reviews.text:
An interesting history of the structure. In important lighthouse for Alexander the Great but earthquakes destroyed the building and it was later converted into a fort.
A tour guide helps.

reviews.title: one of the most beautiful places
reviews.text: it's a wonderful place I have ever seen. I was very exacting and happy because I spent a whole day in this place

reviews.title: Nice place to visit
reviews.text: A nice historic place to visit in Alex... It's worth the time to visit the Citadel too and have a nice picture there...

reviews.title: Foundation of one of the wonders of the ancient western world
reviews.text: While now a restored fort, I was hoping for more information of the lighthouse.  Whether by fame in lore or estimation of current historians/scientist would have been interesting to assemble with the fort restoration.

reviews.title: One of the best attractions in Alexandria
reviews.text: It was one of the wonders of the ancient world, but was destroyed three earthquakes and eventually in 1480 the last remnants of the lighthouse were used to build the Citadel of Qaitbay. In 1477 AD Sultan Al-Ashraf Sayf al-Din Qa'it Bay in an effort to fortify this important Egyptian port from attack, and rubble from the toppled lighthouse was used in its construction.

reviews.title: Qaitbay Citadel : Main attraction of Alexandria
reviews.text: The main attraction of Alexandria . This is called Qaitbay Citadel . There is no lighthouse now.  It is a middle age fortress built on the bank of Mediterranean sea. Very well maintained establishment indeed. Entry fee was 60 Egyptian Pound for adult and 30 for students and locals (2019).

reviews.title: Beautiful site to visit
reviews.text: Great location along the Mediterranean Sea. It is a lovely place for a stroll or to enjoy the area sitting seaside.

reviews.title: Beautiful view
reviews.text: along the Mediterranean sea its a beautiful place to visit. Breathtaking location with  lots of restaurants around is a famous spot for tourists.

reviews.title: Too close but too far
reviews.text: We visited the place and I could imagine having seen documentaries the great wonder of the world it was as explained by Ibn Batuta and other travelers of old times.But place could have been kept better and we were discouraged to go the castle as I understand it is empty. They can create a magic with technology/films/ 3D experiences. Egypt has many lost opportunities. Wish they they can make up.

reviews.title: Almost blew us away
reviews.text: When we went it was extremely windy. So much so that it was hard to take a step forward. The sea right next to it makes it magical. Fantastic experience visiting this.

reviews.title: Amazing views, beautiful building
reviews.text: Awesome Citadel. This place is beautiful and has amazing views of the library and city.  Lots of neat history.  Lots of stairs that are uneven, so may be hard for some to climb inside.  This is a must see and on top of my list for places to see.  Vendors outside can be a bit pushy.

reviews.title: The Citadel
reviews.text: The lighthouse does not exist but now the waterfront citadel is.You will probably stop here after visiting Pompey's pillar. Good photo opportunity if you can time it right during the day, sunset over the sea.

reviews.title: A small but nicely done museum
reviews.text: This museum is small but well-done on three levels covering three eras of Egyptian history.  There is a small selection of artefacts including jewelry, pottery, artwork, statues, etc. Nothing here will wow you, but it is worth a visit. An elevator is available, but a little hard to find.

reviews.title: Nicely done
reviews.text: Great array of artifacts covering several years. Some were recovered from the Mediterranean Sea. A guide is really helpful to understand and appreciate what is on display.

reviews.title: Disappointed
reviews.text: The museum was poorly maintained and very small. I only went because the Greco-Roman Museum was closed. Nothing particularly striking to see. Would not include in one’s itinerary.

reviews.title: Excellent museum in a 1926 Italianate mansion.
reviews.text: We took an Uber($2) 2 km east from our Paradise Inn-Le Metropole Hotel arriving after the 9 AM opening.  After paying 200 Egp ($11) for 2 foreigners, we took a self tour of the 4 floors beginning with the basement level and its clean restrooms.  Adjacent were the featured Old and New Kingdom exhibits including the funerary chamber with its mummy, canopic jars and flakes of gold.  Upstairs continued with Old Alexandria statues recovered from  the sea, then Roman, Coptic and Ottoman exhibits.

reviews.title: Good Museum
reviews.text: I came here with a tour group.  Very nice museum with lots of very nice stuff. Walk around on your own.  Come early to avoid crowds.

reviews.title: How wonderful Alexandria culture
reviews.text: Such a good museum, I really like this experience, I hope to return back again once a day with my children in the future

reviews.title: AC not working I had to make my visit short
reviews.text: I love this museum, every time I am in Alexandra I visit. This time my visit was shorten because there was no AC and the air was sucked from the majority of the rooms that I couldn’t breath. I asked one of the staff and he said the AC isn’t working. Too bad because I wanted to stay longer and take my time.

reviews.title: A don’t miss visit
reviews.text: Accessible easy to reach place with an amazing display and good choice of rare artifacts. Reached there by uber. Ticket was 20LE

reviews.title: A historical figure ❤
reviews.text: This museum as much as simple but have alot if mixed cultures and civilisations had lived in Alexandria through the centuries. Big advice for everyone who comes or willing to visit Alexandria ot keep it in mind this place.🤩👍👌

reviews.title: Wonderful smaller Museum
reviews.text: The Alexandria National Museum was once a mansion, now it's filled with historic treasures. I believe there are four levels to see, so much history you can spend a easy two hours exploring and reading.

reviews.title: Excellent Pharaonic, Greek and Roman collections
reviews.text: Not to be missed.  The lower level has a wonderful Pharaonic collection that is beautifully presented with some of the best lighting I have seen.  Graeco-Roman collection on the ground floor is quite good as well.  Upper floor presentation covering  Islamic and Ottoman was okay but got better sense of the Ottoman period by visiting the Ottoman mansions in Rashid.

reviews.title: Small but interesting museum
reviews.text:
Located in an old turn of the XXth century mansion, this museum includes antiquities and decorative arts objects.
Not surprisingly the highlight is the Egyptian antiquities section which contains some beautiful pieces.
On the other hand the section that includes antiques recently recovered from the sea is rather disappointing

reviews.title: Small but engaging
reviews.text:
We walked to this small out of the way museum housed in a former grand residence of Alexandria. The walk itself was engaging and interesting as we made our way through the backstreets. On arrival, the museum presents as a magnificent old home.
Inside, a wonderful collection through the history of Alexandria is presented with English descriptions. The grounds are equally interesting with marbles and sarcophagus. This is a must see.

reviews.title: Very good !
reviews.text: Fascinating collection of ancient pieces. Really is worth a visit and a good two hour stay if you are with a good tour guide as we were. Hassan from Bunniks really brought this museums displays to life for us. Very memorable.

reviews.title: Average Museum
reviews.text: Given that Alexandria was our last stop in our Egypt tour and we had already spent a lot of time at the Cairo Museum and in Luxor, we did not find the Alexandria Museum to be overly informative above and beyond what we already knew, except for the greco-roman era info. If someone has already visited the other cities in Egypt and the museums there, they can give this one a pass. Overall, the museum was well maintained though, but the pricing for foreigners (100 EGP) was a bit steep in comparison to what it had to offer.

reviews.title: Impressive structure with great views of the city and sea
reviews.text: This simple but impressive fortress is situated in a great location for views of the Alexandria waterfront and of the Mediterranean Sea.  You can enter the fortress and visit the upper level, but be prepared for somewhat step stairways. Stroll around the outer ramparts for great views by staking a stairway to the right of the main fortress entrance.

reviews.title: Very impressive building, little signage
reviews.text: I'm very glad that we came here.  The structure itself is very impressive.  However there is very little signage, so if don't do some research before or after your visit, you won't really know what you're seeing.

reviews.title: Historic site, quick tour, great time!
reviews.text:
We spent two days in Alexandria on a trip to Egypt and I am very glad we did, lots to see and do and we enjoyed our time.

I really wanted to visit the site of the old lighthouse and we totally enjoyed exploring the Citadel of Qaitbay.  We had a guide, which I think always helps appreciate and understand historical sites.  We learned about how they used some of the old Lighthouse in the construction of the citadel, we learned about how it used to be a home for the King to come and stay, etc...  It doesn't take long, I think we were there maybe a total of an hour.  If you are in Alexandria, I certainly wouldn't miss seeing this!

reviews.title: Do not miss attraction of Alexandria
reviews.text:
Nice place to enjoy nature at the backdrop of a old, poorly maintained fort.
Fort has very little to see / enjoy but the scenic natural beauty around the fort will definitely inspire nature lovers / photographers. Definitely the best place to visit @ Alexandria.

There is a small but well maintained aqarium closeby which is also worth a visit.

reviews.title: Amazing
reviews.text: Interesting stop during our Alexandria visit. Great for kids to explore. Not to big, not to small. Very windy while we were there

reviews.title: Panoramic views
reviews.text: The location is amazing as it's directly on the Mediterranean sea, and the views you get from there are breathtaking. Make sure you take a boat ride around the fort its mind-blowing.

reviews.title: Pleasant views.
reviews.text: A nice end to the day trip, fabulous views over this area of the Mediterranean with a nice breeze.  History behind this building is interesting.

reviews.title: Amazing
reviews.text:
Fort Qaitbey is a must while in Alexandria, The history behind the fort is fascinating. The building itself is breathtaking. It’s right on the Mediterranean Sea and the scenery is amazing. 
You have to pay at the entrance before you can get in for a tour. Plenty of free parking.
Make sure you take a boat ride around the Fort and a tour guide to explain the history behind this landmark.
Worth it and very picturesque 
It’s about 2.5 hours drive from Cairo.

reviews.title: Very interesting
reviews.text: We went to visit this Fort in the morning. It was sunny and quite cool. The views from the different areas were stunning when looking to ward the sea. It is really a fortress well planned and ingenious design. The access to different parts and floor levels were well planned. A good piece of work!

reviews.title: An all-around "upper walk" :)
reviews.text:
After going up the rampart on the back side of the citadel grounds (right behind the citadel building), I did my walk-around above the ramparts on all four sides of the grounds in the "clockwise direction" with each side offering a "kind-of-unique" view: an open-sea view (from the back side where the rampart is "two-leveled" and also kind of divided into two halves with a wall at like right about the middle); view of a long stone pier and also that of the city's waterfront skyline seen past that stone pier (from the side after turning right from the back side); view of the "imposing building" of the Citadel looking like a castle or such with a tower at each of its corners (seen "looking back" from the side where the rampart is actually shortly inside the outer wall with the citadel entrance, and yes which is the side where I would say is one for the "best photo-op" with the building); and finally view of more of the city's skyline (from the side after turning right from the entrance side) before coming back down from above the back-side rampart but from its half different from the half where I started.  As for the interior of the citadel building though, it's mainly just for a walk-through along its corridors with not much at all to see (except the area of an "empty mosque", a miniature model of the Citadel & some small areas inside archways just to look through their doors).  There's also the "underground part" (separate from the building itself) which likely once was a collection of jail cells & such judging from its interior architecture although the "only enclosure" there is some rectangular area within four walls (which is not underground itself but can only be reached after going through that underground part of the Citadel).

And quite conveniently for me staying along the waterfront way Corniche at the time, it was just about a 5-minute taxi ride from near my place to this site, and yes also visible from my balcony was a "tiny glimpse" of this building across that small portion of the Mediterranean Sea right past the city's waterfront.

reviews.title: Lovely Sea Fort
reviews.text: This fort was my main reason for coming up to Alexandria, and it did not disappoint. The 3 accessible floors all have different views, and the mosaic mosque floor on the first level is stunning. The views through the small windows in the thick stone walls are breathtaking.

reviews.title: Very beautiful Citadel
reviews.text: Very beautiful citadel and very well-preserved, its location is amazing as it’s directly on the Mediterranean Sea, the views you get from the citadel is breathtaking and amazing, you get the full skyline of Alexandria in front of you, the fresh air there is very cool and amazing, the overall atmosphere is also nice, i highly recommend visiting this beautiful spot in Alexandria but i wouldn’t recommend visiting it on the weekend as it would be extremely crowded with people.

reviews.title: The best attraction in Alexandria
reviews.text: It is definitely worthy of seeing. There is a nice and secure parking spot. Whole site is clean, picturesque and nicely restorated. There is not any exposition but whole fortress and its surrounding is large and you will spend nice time exploring it.

reviews.title: Get a nice view of the city
reviews.text: The fort itself is a challenge to get to by vehicle.  Recommend walking there if you're comfortable with the crowds and being harassed along the way.  It has a great view of the city and the water.  Opted out of the tour and glad I did since there wasn't that much to see of the fort itself.

reviews.title: Very picturesque locale with stunning views.
reviews.text: The Qaitbay Citadel is a very picturesque castle on the Mediterranean coast and dominates the Alexandria harbor.  Interesting history. Very well maintained. The sea facing part lends itself to some unique pictures. Outside the citadel are many stalls selling trinkets- besides the standard stuff there are unique nautical curios and mementos too.

reviews.text:
Great place but avoid the restaurant across from the gate.. He will double charge you.
The Catacomve itself was the most interning thing I seen in Egypt.. Better than the pyramids

reviews.title: Catacombs of Kim El Shoqafa
reviews.text: One of the Seven Wonders of the Middle Ages . Consists of a series of tombs , statues and objects of the pharaonic funeral cult . A circular staircase was used to transport deceased bodies down into the catacombs and tombs . The tombs were tunneled into bedrock during the 2nd century AD . Was discovered in 1900 when a donkey fell into the access shaft . There was even a funeral banquet hall where friends a family gathered at 5he time of the funeral or future visits to the loved ones. An interesting site to visit but lots of stairs leading down into the chambers . Worth the visit …

reviews.title: Worth a visit
reviews.text:
I recently visited the Catacombs of Kom el Shoqafa and found the experience to be both interesting and unique. The Catacombs are a series of underground tombs dating back to the 2nd century AD, and they provide a fascinating glimpse into the funerary customs of ancient Alexandria.

Our guide did an excellent job of explaining the history and significance of the site. The Catacombs themselves are quite extensive, and there is a lot to see, including multiple levels of tombs, an underground cistern, and various statues and carvings. I was especially impressed with the skill and artistry that went into creating these underground tombs.

One of the most interesting features of the Catacombs is the mix of Egyptian, Greek and Roman architectural styles, which is quite unique. The Catacombs also have a unique blend of Pharaonic, Hellenistic and early Christian motifs, which is quite fascinating to see.

It's definitely worth a visit if you're interested in ancient history and architecture. The Catacombs of Kom el Shoqafa are not only an important historical site but also a unique and interesting place to explore.

reviews.title: Must Visit!
reviews.text: A must visit site that is fascinating and enjoyable. Again our Egyptologist, Rabi, ensured that we had all the background information we needed to enhance what we were looking at and experiencing.

reviews.title: Small but interesting
reviews.text: Great stop on our visit in Alexandria. It was smaller than I was anticipating, but impressive nonetheless. About 90+ steps down, but that sound worse than it is

reviews.title: Unexpected “jewel”
reviews.text: The story of the donkey follow through a hole in the ground, what urned out to be the ceiling of a hidden large maze of buried catacombs, an ancient funeral site. Interesting to see what was done nearly 2000 years ago, including the meeting room for the relatives of the deceased. Also the differences between the rich and the poor … and the bones of a horse, assigned to the horse Caracas.

reviews.title: Must visit!
reviews.text: I had not done my research prior to visiting the catacombs, and boy oh boy was I surprised! It is a must visit place for anyone who comes to Alexandria. It is well maintained, and tickets are 80 EGP/person for adults, which is not expensive.

reviews.title: Not like other catacombs
reviews.text:
An interesting place to visit with history that dates back to 1 & 2 BC. A guide is absolutely necessary.
Lots of steps and easy to move around.

reviews.title: Lots of steps . Good but not a must see
reviews.text:
You see so much on your travels in Egypt that sometimes things (that maybe spectacular elsewhere) is just average - you do get spoilt in Egypt !!
There is much to see here and the history behind it is interesting. There are a lot of steps to get to the catacombs so beware. When it is busy people just seem to look after themselves and going up and down the winding stairs can be a challenge.
Ok but not a must see

reviews.title: Just average
reviews.text: Interesting piece of history but definitely not a must stop.  Several floors of catacombs to wander through.  Artifacts on display before you go down

reviews.title: Explore
reviews.text: tiring but it’s worth it something to explore…… it’s nice.. place should be more advertise so everyone can see the place

reviews.title: Fascinating Catacombs in the Middle of the City
reviews.text: A definitely different view of Alexandria. These catacombs are in the middle of the modern city and yet a world apart. Walking down the circular stairs takes you to a unique and ancient burial place. A great experience not to be missed.

reviews.title: Both above & below
reviews.text:
The second of the three "small ruins" of the city all visited on the same day, this is a site despite its "pretty compact" size overall is one with actually "a fair number" of tombs, I would say, where the "main area" is not above but below the site grounds (the above-ground part actually kind of secondary where among a number of tombs scattered are just one or two tombs for "brief entry" into their small interiors).  And, arriving here just a few days after seeing those "awesomely beautiful" tombs of pharaohs in Luxor, I would just describe the tombs at this site as "pretty plain" although yes "somewhat exciting" was going down the spiral staircase to the underground (seen as just a cylindrical structure from above ground but fairly spacious down below with "2 levels") where it was generally worthwhile to see: some tombs with mural scenes & such featuring human & animal figures carved on the exteriors of the tombs, some "actual remains" such as human bones displayed in a glass case & some rows of these open-ended square-shaped compartments which likely were once tombs (maybe of those not so high in social hierarchy).  And yes actually, as for the "stone murals" (on the exteriors of the tombs as just mentioned), the "best one" is not at a tomb below ground but at one above (not a plain mural as those underground but one "vibrant with colors").

With all three sites located just within about a 15-minute taxi ride from one another (including the traffic times in the city streets), I started the day at Roman Theater (just a tiny one with some additional structures around it) then this site followed by Pompey's Pillar (a small hill with a "commemorative pillar" & two modest-sized sphinxes with one on each side of the pillar).

reviews.title: Really worth a visit
reviews.text: Out of all the attractions in Alexandria we found this one to be the most interesting. It is worth a visit, especially with a guide who can explain the history and the symbolism of this place.

reviews.title: Historical archaeological site
reviews.text:
We were treated to this unusual place during our day trip from Cairo
The excavations and fine details from so many years back was rather amazing
A little tight for older adults or people with joint pains to go through this but for relatively fit people it’s a good site to visit
If you have full day worth a visit to see the site

reviews.title: Good place who worth visiting
reviews.text: Large park with extensive amazing view, it is located at Montaza with wide green area, I recommend this place to all visitors to Alexandria

reviews.title: Wait until this construction mess is complete.
reviews.text: This once beautiful garden is under renovation.  The entire garden, not just a section at a time!  Everything is covered with a very visible layer of dust.  It was supposed to be completed in October 2022.  I’m here now and it appears that this project will not be done anytime soon. Getting to our hotel inside the garden is an off road extremely dusty ride. Our driver had to dodge huge machinery.  The view from my balcony is dust and machines and the noise created. I’m on the 6th floor and unable to use my balcony due to the dust and petrol smell from the machinery.  Verify that this is complete prior to visiting as this is not pretty.

reviews.title: Terrible worthless visit
reviews.text: A total destruction and mess, their is ongoing buidding and renovation at site. I recommend no one to go

reviews.title: Lovely and enchanted
reviews.text: I think this is the only place in Alexandria is not destroyed yet by ignorance, great location by the see and very clean and tidy , a good chance to see the real history of the city and how clean it used to be!

reviews.title: A visit "not much worthwhile"
reviews.text:
It's a site which I would simply put as "not meeting expectations" (specifically those of walking in a beautiful garden and seeing a great palace close by and for which I took like an out-of-the-way taxi ride for about 40 minutes from the city center around the Qaitbay Citadel) and which in reality is just a "wooded park" where yes the great palace & its front garden do exist (at about a 5-minute walk from the site entrance along the way kind of gradually "to the left") but only to look at from outside the fence for a "partial view" meaning that of just two sides of the Palace & a very small part of the front garden.  But with that said, it was a "fairly breathtaking" view of some nice colorful architectural patterns & such on those two faces of the Palace with great photo-ops still possible from outside the fence.  And also, located within this site of wooded park are two more structures which I also only viewed from outside: "another palace" apart from the great one (which is nowhere as breathtaking or elaborate as the great one but more like just a "large house" I would say) and a "lighthouse-like tower" of some significant height (which is actually likely possible for going up but which is likely to see not much from above with trees all around it).

And so, also to make the most of visiting this out-of-the-way site of the city, I decided on my way back to get off the taxi in front of the "interesting-shaped" Bibliotheca building along the waterfront way Corniche and then took a "leisure walk" for about an hour with heritage buildings (almost in one continuous row) to my left and the Mediterranean Sea to my right (where to see along the water's edge are a number of people with their fishing rods in the water).

reviews.title: Wait while they finish the reconstruction
reviews.text: The garden is under reconstruction so it is really not worth the visit, especially if you have little time. Two things that we did like, was the palace (which can only be seen from the outside) and the view. The rest is just diggings and the mud.

The locals were taking advantage of the pleasant weather the day we visited. If you are looking for fresh air and a break from historic sights, this is your place.

name: Bibliotheca Alexandrina
ranking_subcategory: #1 of 60 things to do in Alexandria
subcategory_ranking: #1 of 60 things to do in Alexandria
ranking: #1 of 60 things to do in Alexandria
description: Located near the site of the ancient library of Alexandria, this modern version is an eleven-story, cylindrical-shaped building that houses more than eight million books. A re-imagining of Alexandria's ancient Great Library, this gorgeously designed cultural center contains a host of museums as well as one of the modern world's most ambitious libraries. Its architecture - a giant sun disk - presides over the waterfront Corniche, while inside, a huge reading room can hold eight million volumes. Below themain library, visitors can explore a range of beautifully curated exhibitions. TheManuscript Museum with its magnificent collection of ancient texts and scrolls and the Antiquities Museum with its Graeco-Roman antiquities and statuary found during underwater exploration in the harbor are the two prime attractions. But there are also rotating art exhibitions, a permanent Egyptian folk art collection, and a Science Museum and Planetarium that are aimed squarely at children.

reviews.title: A Visit to the Bibliotheca Alexandrina in Alexandria
reviews.text:
I visited the Bibliotheca Alexandrina in Alexandria and was impressed with the facilities. The modern library is a nod to the cultural heritage of Alexandria, which had a reputation as a center of learning in ancient times.

The building's architecture and design are noteworthy, and the collection of books, manuscripts, and other resources is extensive. The library also features interactive exhibits and innovative technologies that make the collection accessible to visitors. It is important to note that access to the library is restricted to children under the age of 4.

Whether you are a student, researcher, or simply interested in learning, the Bibliotheca Alexandrina is worth a visit. Its blend of history, culture, and technology make it a unique experience.

In conclusion, if you are in Alexandria and meet the age requirements, I recommend checking out the Bibliotheca Alexandrina. The library's collection and facilities will give you a deeper appreciation for the city's cultural heritage.

reviews.title: A modern library in front of the Mediterranean
reviews.text: Though I didn’t go inside realizing my time drawing short as the sun sets, I can see the fusion of cultures and telling people what they want to convey.

reviews.title: Highlight of our trip!  More than just a "library"
reviews.text:
A highlight of our trip to Egypt!  We spent two days in Alexandria on a trip to Egypt and I am very glad we did, lots to see and do and we enjoyed our time.

The Library is absolutely stunning!  We went inside and planned on doing the tour, but it didn't start for a little while.  So instead we went downstairs and went through one of their exhibitions (the antiquities), which was fascinating.  Then we headed up for the tour.  Our guide was super engaging and walked us through the many aspects of the library, from its construction, remote access of books and information, permanent displays, etc...

We then walked around and explored the main library itself.  It is massive and awe inspiring, and I don't even normally like libraries! :)

It was hard to believe we spent two hours there!  Time just flew by and I wish we had more time, but our schedule didn't allow for it.

Children are the future and we have the owe to show them how can they become literate /educated themselves.. and they have the right to see libraries, books and culture so was a bit disappointed not to enter freely with children.

reviews.title: A "tiny theater" in a "small complex"
reviews.text:
The first of the three "small ruins" of the city all visited on the same day, this is just quite a small Roman amphitheater with the capacity to accommodate at most a few hundred people I would say (especially having been to two in Jordan before this one and one in Tunisia after this one, all three much larger with capacities "for thousands") although yes I'm not quite sure here if the "amphitheater-like steps" a little apart from the Theater itself were added to its capacity for the performances during its time which would have made quite a bit of difference for the number of spectators (nowadays a pretty good "contrasting view" of like the old & the new with some of the city's skyline visible right behind this site while looking from the top of those steps which are right inside the site entrance before coming down to get to the Theater itself).  And yes, with this theater being part of a "small complex" and not a stand-alone structure, further interior on the site grounds are like small lecture rooms or such with wall partitions in a long rectangular structure (of a Roman school or college back in the day as mentioned on an info sign) and some "bath structures" one of which actually can be gone down a few steps to its area a little below the ground.

And so, located not far apart from one another, all three of the "small ruins" can easily be reached by a taxi ride for just about 15 minutes between any two of them (with some traffic along those city streets around the sites) where I headed next to Catacombs of Kom el Shoqafa (with ancient tombs both above & below the ground and all in just one small area) followed by Pompey's Pillar (a small hill to go up to with a modest-height pillar & two fairly small sphinx statues above).

reviews.title: Interesting Roman amphitheater in Alexandria but it doesn't take long to explore.
reviews.text: The Roman Amphitheater in Kom El-Deka, is the only Roman amphitheater in Egypt, dating back to the 2nd century AD. This theater was made of marble and once seated around 800 spectators with galleries, remains of mosaic flooring, and a recreational garden, surrounded by Roman baths and villas. By the time we got to the archaeological site unfortunately it was raining very heavy and of course I forgot my hat on the bus. I did initially walk over to the site and stayed for a few minutes until the rain became more uncomfortable and I backed up the stairs returning to the group who opted not to get wet and visit the amphitheater. Fortunately the the rain began to let up some what and I found another staircase and went down to the bottom level right next to the amphitheater and took pictures.

reviews.title: Kom el-Dekka
reviews.text: Kom el-Dekka is Arabic for 'Mound of Rubble', a name given in the 19th century to describe how the area once looked. Today’s archaeological site was excavated and conserved through a joint effort between Poland and Egypt from 1960-2008. It features the remains of an ancient Roman theater, Auditoria (lecture halls), Roman baths, cisterns and a small village. The Villa of the Birds is located here. The name was given to the remains of what was once the large house of a wealthy Roman. Dating to the reign of Hadrian, the restored villa has a stunning mosaic floor depicting colorful birds. An elevated walkway provides a viewing platform. The entire site, including the theater, is on the small side but worth the admission fee. We visited with a guide, but the site is well-marked with descriptive plaques, so you could manage here on your own. There were only a few other people strolling the grounds when we visited (and several wild dogs that gave me quite a scare). By the way, like the typical Roman theater, look for the small area center stage that marks the location where your voice is amplified and carries to the whole theater (try this, it's remarkable!).

reviews.title: Kom El-Dekka Site (Roman amphitheater) well worth a look!
reviews.text: Kom El-Dekka Site (Roman amphitheater) is in Alexandria - founded by Alexander the Great. It was a ‘well-off’ residential area in Graeco-Roman times, with lovely villas, bathhouses and a theatre. The amphitheater is a marble theater that once seated 800 spectators. This site also contains Roman columns, artifacts (statues, etc.) pulled from ocean, and other interesting areas related to residential area of the time. Spend time walking around, reading the information signs, and enjoying the sights.

reviews.title: Exploring the Exhibits at the Royal Jewelry Museum in Alexandria
reviews.text:
I recently visited the Royal Jewelry Museum in Alexandria and it was a fascinating experience. The museum showcases an impressive collection of jewelry and other precious artifacts that depict the rich history and culture of Egypt.

Unfortunately, the museum staff were not available during my visit, but the self-guided tour allowed me to explore the exhibits at my own pace. Despite this, the museum was well-organized and provided ample information about the pieces on display, making it easy to understand the significance of each piece.

The museum is beautifully arranged and the attention to detail in preserving the pieces was evident. Whether you're a fan of history, culture, or jewelry, the Royal Jewelry Museum is definitely worth a visit.

In conclusion, I highly recommend the Royal Jewelry Museum in Alexandria to anyone who is interested in learning more about the history and culture of Egypt. The self-guided tour may have been a challenge, but the collection on display was truly captivating.

reviews.title: A jewel in the city
reviews.text:
First, let me respond to some reviewers' comments that their experience was hot or stuffy when they visited the Royal Jewelry Museum. We may have just been lucky, but when we visited there the other day (July 2021), windows were open and cooling breezes were blowing through almost all of the building. To ensure you have a comfortable visit, why not just go early in the day? They open at nine a.m.

I won't bother with all the details of what's included: the facts are elsewhere for you to read. It's an important place in Alexandria history, truly beautiful, and it was actually a residence for many years. 

If you, like I and so many others have, fall in love with the exceptional tilework in the royal bathroom, then be sure to take a peek through the beveled glass doors to the right, looking up from bottom of the staircase on the first floor. You should be able to see some different exceptionall tiles, in an area which must be part of the kitchen. It wasn't open to the public when we visited, so it's a bit of a teaser, once you've seen that gorgeous bathroom. 

Perhaps the museum offers a place for refreshments in non-covid times, but nothing like that was open on the premises when we were there. We gave ourselves a nice post-museum break at the Cilantro cafe, around the corner and down the block. Ecuador, across the tram line from the museum, is very good too.

reviews.text:
Among the many wonderful sites we visited in Alexandria, was the Royal Jewelry Museum located no more than a 5 minute drive from the Four Seasons hotel.

This 2-story palace housing the Jewelry collection of Egypt’s Royal family originally belonged to Princess Fatma El Zahraa. 

The palace itself is certainly the most precious jewel as the flooring and ceilings and staircase are unbelievably stunning.

Must see for all visitors.

Ashraf El Khadem
Egyptian Express Travel

reviews.title: The best place in Alexandria to relax after sightseeing marathon
reviews.text:
Yes, it's nice, safe and relatively clean. After terribly dirty and polluted Cairo Alexandria seems like paradise anyhow and the place only accentuates this impression. Take a horse and buggy ride - "carriages" are damn old and dilapidated, almost ramshackle but still quite reliable and fares are ridiculously low - just ten bucks per hour irrespective of whether you are alone or a couple.
So hop on, listen to hoofbeats, see your coachman greeting and talking (!) to his colleagues while driving - what else a tourist needs after all these see-to-the-lefts and see-to-the-rights? Nirvana...
The guys hardly speak any language except for Arabic though.

reviews.title: Alexandria’s Waterfront Road
reviews.text: The Corniche is a waterfront road that runs for 10 miles through the heart of Alexandria. It stretches from Qaitbay Citadel, on the west end, to Montaza on the east. Lots of activity here – plenty of restaurants, cafes, and beaches make it the perfect place to people-watch and soak up the atmosphere. This is a major traffic corridor, so unless you are walking, be prepared for major traffic delays. The good news is that since the Corniche runs along the Mediterranean, you will be able to enjoy beautiful sea views while sitting in traffic. And the Corniche is the perfect place to watch the sun set (unfortunately we watched from the car).

reviews.title: Pompey's Pillar
reviews.text: Ptolemy I founded the great Temple of Serapeum dedicated to the Greek-Egyptian god Serapis around 300 BC. It stood for over 600 years as one of the most important religious and intellectual centers in the Mediterranean. It is said the temple was destroyed by Bishop Theophilus and Christian mobs in 391 AD. You can view the ruins today at the site of Pompey’s Pillar. We visited with a guide that helped us to understand the historical importance of the area.

reviews.title: Old and New
reviews.text:
If you visit the Sarapeum, you will see Pompey's Pillar. If you visit Pompey's Pillar, you will be in the Sarapeum. It's pretty much all in the same location.

This spot housed a large temple with views of land and sea. Eventually it was destroyed - some blame Roman soldiers, others blame a mob of Christians. 
Below there are catacombs but I never saw it. As you walk around the complex toward the pillar, there will be areas with ruins and relics to look at. It doesn't take much time at all to walk through the artifact garden. It's nice to walk through and take the time to look at the modern buildings creeping up around you. 

You don't really need a guided tour of this location, but a little bit of background information helps. It's a fast visit and won't take up much of your time.

reviews.title: Interesting juxtaposition of Egyptian and Greek influence

reviews.title: Part of Pompey's Pillar

reviews.title: Sadly Mostly Ruins
reviews.text: The Serapeum, also spelled Sarapeum, or Sarapieion, was dedicated to the worship of the Greco-Egyptian god Serapis (Sarapis).  Although most of the area surrounding the Pompey’s Pillar is unrecognizable rubble, there are remnants of a Roman bath and piscina.  A piscina is a shallow basin placed near the altar of a church, or in the vestry or sacristy, used for washing the communion vessels.  Wear walking shoes.  Look around you may find an underground entrance to what is left of the Temple of Serapeurm.

reviews.title: Magnificent structure in ancient times

reviews.title: Few remainings

reviews.title: pretty neat Pompey's Pillar and the Sarapeum

reviews.title: Cute Cavafy place
reviews.text:
A small and cute museum, ex house of the big poet. For people who love Cavafy, it is a very nice place with a great collection of his works. It is not very easy to find it as there are no signs but if you are lucky you will meet a very kind local man (sells cute souvenirs) who will show you the staircase to the museum.

As Greeks, we were truly enthusiastic that the man in the museum speaks Greek!

reviews.title: Everything Cavafy!
reviews.text:
Constantine P. Cavafy is most probably my favorite poet so you can imagine my excitement when visiting his former home where he lived for the last 25 years of his life. 

I was pretty much awe struck, knowing that this was the street he often walked along, standing at the window’s he often stood at, looking out into his beloved Alexandria. Most of his furniture - seen in the old photo’s of the apartment - have gone although there still are alot of beautiful pieces, along with many writings and photos. Unfortunately they do not sell any books. 

The museum didn’t have much in English so I recommend using a translation app to scan the text into the language that you need. On the day I visited it was free although gave a donation. If you are trying to tap into a former vision of Alexandria, a former century, nostalgia, then you will find it here.

reviews.title: Nice Museum
reviews.text: A small museum in the heart of Alexandria. It is basically the house where Cavafy lived. Plan for 30-45 minutes for the visit.

reviews.title: For admirers of the poet
reviews.text: Cavafy is regarded by many as the single most important poet of modern Greece. So, a visit to his house, despite the chaotic traffic of Alexandria, is a necessary tribute to his poetic genious by his admirers. Well taken care of, small, but an emotional experience for the more poetic souls.

reviews.title: The home of the great Greek poet
reviews.text: The house where the great Greek poet lived! In the rooms of the house there are all the objects and books of Cavafy! His office, his bed, his collections! A visit to the museum is worth it, especially if you are Greek or you admire the work of the poet!

reviews.title: Facinating to travel back in time.
reviews.text: We just toured the outside. Egypt is the land of history & antiquities so depending on how much time you have to spend in Alexandria should determine if this is what you want to see or not.

reviews.title: Where poets create greatness
reviews.text:
Cavafy museum is hosted on the second floor of an old turn of the century house in a small side street.
There is where the Great poet lived and created. At his time Alexandria was a multinational city where Greek, Jews, Armenians and others lived and prospered. Arabic element was a minority. This district was filled with night entertainment to a man's darkest desires. 
There is where he inspired and lived. The apartment is filled with pictures of his younger and latter years, his handwritten will and birth certificate in Greek, many scripts and books. Some publications are also sold for providing an income for the preservation of the place. 
The furniture is not antiques but true replicas of the original, with the exception of a couple of pieces. 
It is worth a visit as from this place stems part of the world literature that belong to all people.

reviews.title: " The City "
reviews.text:
" I will go to another city better than this one " Cavafy museum, cavafy museum just two steps from Madam Christina cafe or Elite Cafe in Safia Zaghloul Street. As l read a bit about that great poet l knew that he born in April 1863 and died in April 1933 and he laying in the Greek Community Cemetery in Alexandria. Cavafy grow up in very rich family, cavafy used to have one brother and one sister but that brother and sister died so cavafy became the only boy that the mother had, on that time his mother took very care of him so much, as she used to bring the teacher at home for cavafy and after cavafy sister died the mother became so sad for the death of her daughter so she used to dress cavafy as girls as well as cavafy stayed most of his life with his mom in Alexandria, we all knew that in Greece and Italy long time ago and in some other European countries lots of wars happened so people escaped from there countries, and as first port for them at the Mediterranean was Alexandria so they found a peace in Alexandria so they lived in it and they built there own clubs, churchs and cemeteries as well. So cavafy family done the same they escaped from crete in Greece and they came to Alexandria, cavafy also used to travel between Hong Kong and Istanbul but he found himself more in Alexandria as he used to work a small work in irrigation authority in Alexandria plus when he became forty he started to write poets, one of his famous poet is
" The City " which l started my conversation with here as well l cry always when l read it l don't know why but if you notice you will see most Cavafy poets is sad poets may be cause the life he lived was full of sadness moments. If you visited Cavafy museum you will be back and you will feel the years which passed away from when you first enter from the door of the house building, really l think Cavafy was the greatest poet in that profound time. The photos attached the first photo the Greek Community cemetery 2nd photo Elite Cafe which already closed totally now 3rd photo my only pretty lady god rest her soul Madam Christina Costantinos owner of Elite Cafe god rest your soul Madam Christina l love so much

reviews.title: Amazing Look at Cavafy
reviews.text:
About a 15 minutes easy walk from The Cecil, this small museum is well worth seeing for anyone who loves Cavafy and his poetry.
GPS makes it easier to find - it's on a narrow side street and then two floors up, but the reward is so worth it.

reviews.title: A very interesting experience!
reviews.text: At a corner of a narrow Alexandria's street you see an apartment house like any other of this city. Entering and heading to the second floor, where Cavify's apartment, you get a very clean impression of how these prewar buildings were looking. The museum itself is very well kept, although most of the furniture are replicas, based on original photos. You will see a big collection of photos of the poet and his family as well as a very rich collection of the editions of his poems and books on him. A visit there is more a must-do pilgrimage to one of the most important poets, not so widely known, of late 19th early 20th century. You get also an idea on how the city's middle class used to live in this multinational multicultural city at the beginning of the 20th century.

reviews.title: A must for any Cavafy fan
reviews.text: Many people (even locals) don't know about this small museum. It's a great experience to visit the place where the Cavafy lived and see his belongings, photos and some of his writings. The neighborhood is also a nice place to walk into. The place is very near Raml station but better to check it in the map before you get there because it is not well known.

reviews.title: A must for poetry lovers!
reviews.text: This rather hidden 'museum' was the residence of Greek poet Kavafis and is definitely a must for Greeks and poetry lovers. It´s surely thrilling to walk around the house where K.P.K. wrote his poems and spent his days and nights in his beloved Alexandria...

reviews.title: a special place
reviews.text: I read "Ithaca" in English when I visited and then museum curator read it in Greek. It was a very special visit for me and I am grateful the place was open. Thank you.

reviews.title: Considered a "Must" for All visitors to Alexandria!
reviews.text:
How could we be visiting Alexandria and not pay a visit to Cavafy’s house! It is way too interesting especially if you are Greek.

A place of pilgrimage even before its transformation into a museum, Cavafy's last home is considered a "must" for all visitors to Alexandria.

The Museum contains a wide range of bibliographical material, translations of Cavafy's poetry in 20 languages by 40 different scholars, and most of the 3,000 articles and works written about his poetry.

His flat is in Sharm el-Sheikh Street which is nowadays a tribute to his life and a major attraction for anyone on an Alexandrian literary pilgrimage. 

The Greek Alexandrian poet found fame and recognition for his writing after his death. He spent his working life as a journalist and civil servant. 

The Cavafy Museum is run under the auspices of the Cultural Section of the Greek Embassy in Cairo.

Open from Tuesday – Sunday from 10:00 – 15:00
Thursdays & Sundays from 10:00 – 17:00

reviews.title: Spiritual Place
reviews.text:
The monastery is located some distance from Alexandria and getting there was an adventure in itself Google Maps was surprisingly good).
The site is of significant importance to Christians as it hosts the relics of St. Minas. The place was busy with local tour groups. There is no entrance fee and the grounds were decorated with beautiful paintings and mosaics. There are also vendor booths with both religious items and local foods.

reviews.title: A must for every Orthodox Christian - and not only for him/her
reviews.text:
There's a charming Coptic icon in the Louvre: Jesus stands beside a man, putting his right hand on his right shoulder. Me and my wife were spellbound by that scene, by naive, sort of childish faces so unusual for us Russians to see on an icon and decided to dig a little bit deeper. 
Now we know much more about the Copts and when planning a trip to Egypt could not afford to miss St Mina Monastery - it was him depicted on that icon. I'd abstain from describing his life and martyrdom here but one thing is certain - it is one of numerous albeit much less known gems of this country.
Though situated not that far from Alexandria, it is not so easy to find since there are no signs in English. So use your GPS - or take a local guide.
The complex is heavily guarded because of muslim fanatics' attacks on the Copts several years ago (no worries - now it's safe there) but it is calm and piety that reign inside. Spacious, impeccably clean, elegant landscape design, imposing architecture, serious but good-natured monks. Quite by chance we met the father superior - an old grey-haired man with a beard - and he gracefully told us the story of the place.
The main church is naturally Orthodox but differs so much from the tradition we are used to in Russia. Nevertheless, you literally feel Divine Grace coming upon you there and leave the complex light and peaceful.
We loved every moment of that visit.
It is the largest Coptic monastery in Egypt, by the way. Which means it is the largest in the world.

reviews.title: Very spiritual
reviews.text:
Highly recommended to visit and get blessing of that place where a saint called Mina from rich family chose to live in the desert by his own choice and gave away everything to the poor to just give his life to lord Jesus .
You could attend a liturgy Wednesday morning and spend some time there and eat the delicious oily bean with bread that has specific taste all for free.
Accept donation if you want but not a must.
I am sure you will visit that place again and again if you went once .

reviews.text:
I love the place. Great architecture. St. Mina historical city  (4th century) is amazing. You can see the Coptic-byzantine style.

reviews.title: Christianity
reviews.text: Our tour guide and driver took us for a day trip from Alexandria to the Saint Mina Monestary.  It's around an hour drive and consists of the old, antiquated, original village and then the Monastery,  Our understanding is that Saint Mina's body was originally buried in the old village and this is the locations the miracles happened that designated him as a Saint.  We met a Coptic Priest in the original village and enjoyed the tour.  There is a quit and calm sense here.  The Monastery we went to afterwards was the famous photographs and the huge complex.  It is still worth the visit but we enjoyed the old village more.  The Monestary serves a plate of beans to everybody and they have a row of booths that act as the gift shops for the Monestary.  Well worth the trip if you want to see Christianity alive and well in the Alexandria area.

reviews.title: if you want to feel spirituality good you must visit it

reviews.title: A coptic Monastery
reviews.text: A Coptic Monastery in the middle of the dessert, very near to the city Alexandria. His holiness pop Kirollos the 116 pop of Alexandria is buried there.

reviews.title: Oasis of Calm
reviews.text:
A delightful place to visit, very calm and peaceful and very well maintained by the Coptic Monks that reside there. The monastery is located at a place in the Western Desert that Saint Mina was buried circa 3rd, 4th century AD. The place used to be desert but with the spread of irrigation from the Nile river, the area is now becoming agricultural ( so don't expect to see sweeping sand dunes). The monastery is a large compound surrounded by high walls and is dominated by a church that is dedicated to St. Mina. There is a chapel on one side of the cathedral  where the remains of St. Mina are interred. 

The monastery is about 90 minute drive from Alexandria and probably about 2.5 to 3 hours from Cairo. If you go from Alexandria take the slightly longer desert road to avoid the Lake Mariout industrial area of Alexandria (the backside of Alex which is not very picturesque). 

Within the compound there is the cathedral to St. Mina, as well as an area with shops stalls that sells religious items and local food, desert plants, and a guest house that serves free bowls of foul (beans) and tea to all visitors - no questions asked and they are very generous. The foul and tea are very clean and tasty. Apparently this is common practice at all Egyptian Monasteries that are open to tourists, i.e. you are treated as a pilgrim and food and drink is provided for free.

The cathedral is very impressive and has some very intricate art work and murals. This is all modern art that was built in the last 40 years under the patronage of the last Coptic Pope, who was the driving force behind the construction of the monastery, and he is interred in the crypt at the back of the cathedral. 

One of the monks speaks English very well and can give tours of the cathedral. . 

Next to the monastery, about 500 meters out into the desert are the archaeological remains of the Byzantine church that was built for St. Mina.  You need a car or be prepared for about a 30 minute walk to reach the site. It is not well marked so you would need someone to show you how to reach the ruins. 

The archaeological site is guarded by a group of Coptic men (and their 4 watch dogs) and they are also tour guides. You would need a Egyptian speaker guide to help with the translations there. 

The whole place is very well maintained and there is no tipping accepted by anyone (even the guys out at the archaeological site would not take tips) . If you would like to give donations then you can give directly to the Monks. They are willing to accept donations for the poor.

reviews.text: Saint Mark's is located in a very interesting section of Alexandria.  It is interesting and I enjoyed the history of the place.  I would include this on the Must See list.

reviews.title: Saint Mark the Evangelist
reviews.text: Due to the suicide bombing of 2017, security around the Christian neighborhood of St. Mark’s is tight. To enter the area, the police held our passports, which were returned to us when we left. The church is named after Saint Mark the Evangelist, author of the second Gospel. St. Mark moved to Alexandria later in his ministry and founded the first Church of Alexandria around 50 AD. The lovely church you see today, built in 1952, stands on the same site.  St Mark was martyred in 68 AD and a miraculous storm prevented the pagans from burning his body. The Christians were then able to carry him away and bury him in a cave under the church. It is said that the saint’s body was stolen in 828 AD and taken to Venice, but other relics remain in the church. Our guide asked a church caregiver to unlock the entrance to the crypt for us. We passed through a vestibule decorated with mosaics describing St. Mark’s life. Steps then descended to a hallway where we could peer through a window to a shrine and relics of the saint. I had not expected this, what a surprise! A spiritual visit for those of the faith.

reviews.title: Centre of the Coptic Church
reviews.text: St Mark's Coptic Orthodox Cathedral is named after St Mark the evangelist, founder of the Coptic Church. It is the seat of the Coptic Pope. The catdhedral is of relatrively recent construction, even though the Coptic Church is one of the oldest denominations in the world.  Joseph and Mary took the baby Jesus to Egypt to escape Herod's slaughter of the innocents.

reviews.title: Great visit

reviews.title: Historic Church
reviews.text: I was fortunate enough to visit this church during the Friday Prayer Service; it was so fascinating to experience this.  One first notices the smoke filling the space from the incense.  And then there is the sound of people praying facing forward.  But also there were lots of worshippers talking among themselves; it all seemed like organized chaos as the priests in front performed their rituals.  Tradition has it that St. Mark himself is buried under this church and my guide repeated that to me; I have my doubts.  This is one of the important sites to visit while even on a brief stay in Alexandria.  My tour guide was helpful in navigating all the intricacies of finding the church, getting past security, and entering the church while the service was taking place.

reviews.title: The See of St Marc the Apostole
reviews.text:
This church is built in the place of the very first church in the African Continent. St. Marc the Evangelist and Apostle was martyred while leading the Holy Mass service Easter Sunday Mass on May 8, 68 and his body was buried there until Venetian  sailors stole the body by bribing the guards and hiding the body under Pork meat (As shown in the paintings outside Basilica St Mack in Venice).
On the 1900th Anniversary of his martyrdom, the body of St.Marc was returned to Egypt by Pope Cyril VI

reviews.title: Must-see in Alexandria
reviews.text: The pillar and the 2 sfinx (both without the nose) or worth the visit as such. However, the underground “small” library makes it exceptional. What an impressive space, just a pity the books and papyruses aren’t there anymore. Take your time, but be careful not to slip over the dusty floors and stairs and not to twist your ankles dues to the poorly illuminated floors that aren’t always regular.

reviews.title: A "small hill" to go up
reviews.text:
The last of the three "small ruins" of the city all visited on the same day, this site I would say is one for the "most underwhelming" (with the least to see among the three) where to do is just to go up a small hill to see close-up a "commemorative pillar" of some significant height (but just not one for much impression) & two sphinxes of modest sizes one on each of two opposite sides of the Pillar (with somewhat of an appearance of "guarding the Pillar" between them).  And, kind of an addition to those above the hill, to see at the bottom of the hill while going along the "specific path" on the way to the hilltop are some more pillars (likely remains of the buildings once existed) & a number of sculptures on display (likely those excavated from this very site where yes the work likely is an "ongoing one" from what I saw).  Also, if you're into souvenir shopping, there's a nice row of small vendors in like one long building on one side of the site grounds below the hill.

With all three sites located within just about a 15-minute taxi ride from one another (including the traffic times in the city streets), I started the day at Roman Theater (just a "tiny theater" with some additional structures around it in a small complex of ruins) followed by Catacombs of Kom el Shoqafa (the site of tombs both above & below ground) before arriving at this "last stop" for the day.

reviews.title: Historical recap

reviews.title: Little but nice archeological site
reviews.text: It is a nice pictureque place surrounded by poorer district of Alexandria. The site consists of a great pillar, two spinxs and small outdoor exposition of excravations of Ptolemaic era. You will spend there 30-45 minutes. It is not a must see atraction but a worthy place to see.

reviews.title: Multi level ruins
reviews.text: The legend that the pillar was so named because Pompey’s head was kept on top of it for a long time is probably not based on fact, but the pillar itself is impressive, having been carved out of a single piece of granite. Half an hour is sufficient to tour the whole complex, including the Sanctuary.

reviews.title: Good background for pics

reviews.title: Impressive pillar within Alexandria
reviews.text: Worth a stop for half an hour or so while in Alexandria. There is a path around the site, and one can get close to the pillar and get some good photos. Impressive pillar carved from granite and somehow transported to the city many centuries ago. There are restrooms and several gift stores at the site.

reviews.title: Underwhelming site
reviews.text: Entrance fee is 80 EGP, which was included in our tour. The site is an underwhelming Roman site that has 1 Pillar and two small Sphinx. There are better sites to visit.

reviews.title: Dispensável / Dismissable
reviews.text:
Nesse local estaria a antiga biblioteca de Alexandria, mas atualmente existe apenas algumas ruínas bem destruídas e uma grande coluna que dá nome ao lugar. Não achei nada demais!

This would be the ancient library of Alexandria, but today there are only a few ruins well destroyed and a large column that gives the place its name. I didn't think anything was too much!

reviews.title: Roman Triumphal Column
reviews.text: Pompey’s Pillar is the name of a Roman triumphal column. The reference to Pompey is a misnomer, assigned mistakenly by early travelers. The pillar was dedicated sometime around 297-303 AD in honor of the Roman Emperor Diocletian and would have supported a massive statue of him. Made of red Aswan granite, the tapered column now stands about 89 ft (27 m) high and 9 ft (2.7 m) at its base. I felt very tiny standing next to this massive structure! The pillar is flanked by two sphinxes brought from Heliopolis. There’s not much else here. The remainder of the site is basically the ruins of the Temple of Serapeum and Rhakotis, the ancient town from which Alexandria grew. Nevertheless, it is worth a visit,  because Pompey’s Pillar is the only ancient monument remaining whole and standing in all of Alexandria today.

reviews.title: Pompey's Pillar
reviews.text: Well worth the stop, great views! You can spend 1.5 hours walking around the site pretty easy. There are pretty straight forward instructions how to get around the site. There is some uneven ground towards the top, so be careful if you have problems walking on uneven ground. Nice gift shop and clean toilets.

reviews.title: Beginnings of the Library?
reviews.text: A very interesting ruin with chambers for document storage and the temple ruins marked on ancient maps.

reviews.title: To costly to see the Pillar.
reviews.text: Pompey's Pillar is a Roman triumphal column in Alexandria, Egypt, the largest of its type constructed outside the imperial capitals of Rome and Constantinople, located at the Serapeum of Alexandria. The only known free-standing column in Roman Egypt which was not composed of drums, it is one of the largest ancient monoliths and one of the largest monolithic columns ever erected. The monolithic column shaft measures 20.46 m in height with a diameter of 2.71 m at its base. Actually has nothing to do with Pompey and was instead set up in AD 292 in honor of Diocletian, who supplied food for the starving population after the siege of the city. In my opnion the price of the Ticket is to high just to see this.

reviews.title: A Roman pillar stands next to the sphinx
reviews.text: A small tourist spot which takes you only 40 to 60 minutes to stay, you can read the instructions to know more about this place and take nice photos here.

reviews.title: KING FAROUS PALACE
reviews.text: Amazing building and more amazing gardens. Some of the info here is incorrect. After The King was kicked out of Egyptian 1952 by Nasser , they turned the main building into a museum to show the Egyptian people how rich and corrupt the King was while his people were poor. I remember being there in 1959 to 1964 , as we lived in Alexandria. They showed off his stamp collection , coin collection etc etc. In late 60s and 1970  they used it to run concerts by Egyptian rock bands "Black Coats" and "le petit chat". As for the 365 wives, not quite correct. Farouk was a Womanizer and had a separate smaller building for his lady friends which is open today as a hotel. Farouk was also a kleptomaniac.  He drove around Alexandsria in a red convertable and no one else was allowed a red car as he wanted people to know it was him. Then Sadat closed it down in the 70s as he believed it was disrespectful. After Sadat came Mubarak who used it as a guest house for himself and diplomats. The main building has been closed the past 20 years and just sitting there gathering dust. The grounds have alwasy been open to the public. I have an old video from 1959 running around as a 4 year old in the balcony. Good old days. Long gone

reviews.title: Locked palaces neither serve the nation nor tourism
reviews.text: I felt little sad as our guide told me about the the palace which is not open to public ever since revolution of 1952. It was being painted and polished . What for? Like any other country they can attract lot of tourists who want to see palaces from inside . Guide told that city wants it to be opened or else Alex has limited attractions.

reviews.title: Great Palace
reviews.text: We were told that the public is not permitted to this palace. Our guide told that this king had 365 wives and he had built this Palace with 365 rooms. (mmmmmmm I don't know how they managed) The external garden is really nice and breathtaking. This is one of the heaven for photographers.

reviews.title: Beautiful palace and gardens
reviews.text: The place is pretty but the real gem is the grounds.  Some beautiful views of the ocean from the grounds of the palace.  We visited the harbor and walked around. The bridge is very pretty. Lots of good photo opportunities.

reviews.title: Beautiful gardens.
reviews.text: We only visited the exterior of the Palace, the beach and the gardens. The gardens are stunning and extensive. Well worth a look.

reviews.title: Pretty and sunset
reviews.text: King Farouk's summer palace in Alexandria is not open to the public, but the extensive grounds are open.  There you'll see Egyptian brides and grooms having photo shoots, people strolling the gardens, and picnickers enjoying the sunset.  It's an interesting structure and worth a visit if you've come to Alexandria for other reasons, but not a principal destination.

reviews.title: The closed palace
reviews.text: While the exterior of the building is very interesting if is not possible to enter. The surrounding gardens are well kept and pretty and full of families enjoying gardens.

reviews.title: A BEAUTIFUL PALACE

reviews.title: Excellent building

Nice time of year to visit.

reviews.title: Only from the outside

The palace was built from 1940 to 1945 but following the revolution in 1952, this place has been raided and today it remains behind locked gates in the Montazah gardens and used only for official purposes.

So we couldn't go in to view the palace and basically just stopped over for a few minutes to take photos from the outside. 

Just outside the palace however is a small garden with a beautiful bridge made of logs and a lovely view of the sea. 

Only drop by if you are spending the day at Alexandria but otherwise not worth the travel all the way for it.

reviews.text: It opens only for prayer times because of covid .The only place i saw destitute and beggars outside the masjid in Alexandria.

reviews.title: Dedicated to 13th century Muslim saint
reviews.text: This gorgeous cream-colored Islamic mosque is dedicated to a 13th century Muslim saint. Built on the site of an earlier 18th century mosque that covered the saint’s tomb, today’s mosque was last restored in 1943. It is impressive, both inside and out. Women and men worship separately and have separate entrances (first time I experienced this in a mosque). Ladies bring a head cover; shoes are left at the entrances. We visited with a guide who waited for us by the ladies’ side door. When we were done inside, we took a walk around to the back of the mosque. It is a shame the area is littered with so much trash.

reviews.title: One of the ancient mosques in Alexandria
reviews.text: The Abu al-Abbas al-Mursi Mosque of Alexandria is dedicated to the 13th century Murcian Andalusi Sufi saint Abul Abbas al-Mursi, his tomb is built inside. Located in a crowded narrow lane in the Anfoushi neighborhood of Alexandria, near the Citadel of Qaitbay. The mosque was redesigned and built in today's current form by Eugenio Valzania and Mario Rossi in the years 1929/1945, and was highly influenced by Egypt's Old Cairo buildings and architecture. The complex is huge. The entrance of the mosque is used by Men. The mosque also has the place for the female to say their prayer. The mosque is an active place of worship. At the time of visiting the mosque women need to cover their heads; arms and legs and all visitors will need to leave their shoes prior to entering the mosque.

reviews.title: Good architecture
reviews.text: The mosque is in working condition and we need to follow their rules of religion during visit .cover you head with stole or scarf.The complex is huge with three mosques inside .The entrance of the mosque is used by Men and for women,take side path to enter.They have shoes stand outside entrance.Though it is free the people standing nearby ,ask for money .

reviews.title: Tourist attaction

reviews.title: Evening visit

reviews.title: Intricate interior design

A famous landmark of this area, the most beautiful mosque they say and rightfully so.

Women can’t enter from the main door, so we had to go thru the side door on the right which leads us into a partitioned area where there’s a side door where our guide was waiting. The interior design is beautiful, especially the wooden carvings and the ceiling when light comes through it. 

Photos are allowed discretely.

reviews.text: Alexandria zoo will soon be considered a farm if died animals are not replaced. Young kids will be happy anyway to ride a pony and feed monkeys, birds and goats. Lions are still there but in unclean condition. The zoo was interesting in the old days so visitors will enjoy the old trees and remaining good lakes. It is ok to enjoy a sunny day away from the busy city at the zoo but donot expect to see varieties of animals and avoid the visit in the weekends or main holidays!

reviews.title: Best Zoo ever
reviews.text: You start off looking at Ibis and goats... but then it goes nuts. For the princely sum of 20 egyptian pounds, I played with a sea lion, held a lion cub, fed a zebra and got strangled by a python. The zoo is not pretty to look at, and you will feel pretty sad for the animals, but it really is a great place for anyone who isn't used to these sort of animals.

reviews.title: Touching Tribute to Egyptian Seafaring History
reviews.text: The Alexandria Unknown Naval Soldier Memorial is dedicated to unknown soldiers who lost their lives in sea battles. It was originally designed as a memorial to Khedive Ismail (Ismail the Magnificent) but was repurposed after the 1952 Egyptian Revolution to commemorate fallen naval personnel. The memorial is located on the Corniche, so you will likely see it without even trying (we passed by twice). A touching tribute to Egyptian seafaring history.

reviews.title: A beautiful monument

It was built under the rule of Muhammed Ali of Egypt. The place is nice to take some photos , but as the place is very crowded and taking photos was not an easy. You can also enjoy the sea view cross the road.

reviews.text: I thought Alexandria was a nice break from the hustle and bustle of Cairo, but the Necropolis was the best part by far. It was well worth going down into the tombs and seeing the intricate architecture below. Definitely try to make it here while you're in Alexandria!

reviews.title: Not a bg site but very interesting
reviews.text: This is a Roman crypt, you enter down the stairs which surround an open "well" where they lowered the bodies.  Below there were rooms with shelves where the bodies were laid.  There was also a large open area with a table where the relatives would gather to eat and mourn the dead.  There was another section which was found more recently where winning jockeys and their horses were buried!  It had a separate entrance.  Go early before the tour buses.
