reviews.title: Most do not know it exists
reviews.text: So its funny because the street is named after this and yet no one knows these exist. I asked locals how far ahead it was on the street and everyone said "your on the street" i said i know but the tombs? haha. Anyway i can see why, they are very small and rarely visited. Still worth a look IF your in the area or curiosity but doe snot warrant a visit on its own. not compared to rest of sites and tombs in Alexandria or Cairo or greater Egypt. If you compare to those not really impressive. Itll take less then an hr to walk down to tombs and then see ones outside. Actually, more like 20 mins.

reviews.title: Important for Cyprus connection
reviews.text: This minor site requires a taxi ride to get there. One of tombs was closed. I wanted to see the better preserved tomb because of its similarity to the Royal Tombs of Paphos. Otherwise not much to see here. Otherise, not worth the cost of admission. The map that I bought at the Bibliotheca Alexandrina showed a Ptolemaic cemetery nearby. Across the street at the back on this necropolis behind a red brick wall we found the Ptolemaic cemetery. It must be viewed from the inside of a housing complex. Nicely designed. It would be great if the two complexes could be joined by a tunnel under the street.

reviews.title: Skip it if you are going to Luxor

reviews.title: Small and quick visit
reviews.text:
These are 4 subterranean rock-cut tombs of a relative good condition and beautiful depictions. They date back to the Ptolemaic era, particularly the 2nd and 3rd century BC.

The tombs were discovered in 1933 when the government decided to level the ground to build a soccer court leading to this magnificent find.

Near the tombs were military barracks named after the famous Egyptian nationalist figure Mustafa Kamel who died in 1908, hence came the name of the tombs.

reviews.title: Interesting
reviews.text: Even if the place is somehow left abandoned when you enter the site your impression change  very interesting specially the bassorilievi  inside the catacombs

reviews.title: Unexpected
reviews.text: This necropolis is a hidden gem. There are actually 4 tombs. start your visit with number 3 and 4 -as they are more ruined then head to No 1 and 2 which are great. The tombs are quite complex . they have stairs, small temples inside, offerings tables, wells, one has 6 sfinxes, and some mortuary chambers. One big sarcofagus lays in the courtyard. It seems there were tombs of high class romans. tombs are dated  end of 3rd Century-beg 2nd Century BC. they were discovered in 1934.  I believe the whole area was a bigger necropolis but actual authorities built over their heritage. As a proof you can take a look behind the necropolis (still guarded by concrete fences) you will find the ruins of Ptolemaic Period that were surrounded by a thin fence (during Mubarak's time) and completely exposed now to anybody (the metal fence disappeared) . These ruins will soon disapear under a garbage hill  produced by inhabitants of the buildings above.

reviews.title: Roman period tombs
reviews.text:
I visited Mustafa Kamel Necropolis in December 2009. The location is in Roushdy (west of Stanley Bridge). As you are heading towards the Corniche from the tram track the entrance is on the left (sign only in Arabic). Entry cost is 20 EGP for foreigners. There were no other visitors when 2 of us visited.
This site dates from around the 11th century BC, I believe. There are two underground sections (only one was open on my visit) and considerable restoration has been done, with a lot of concrete used. Enter the doors and down about 25 steps to get to the subterranean rto see the rock-hewn tombs. There are some coloured wall paintings visible alongside remains of small sphinxes. Outside there is a small garden area with a large sarcophagus in good condition. There is another section of tombs that are open to the elements and these are in particularly poor condition. It is just about possible to see the cuttings into the sandstone rock where the coffins were put. The dead have long since been removed from these tombs.
The garden has aloes, fig tree and a few nice plants but there is nowhere for visitors to sit, so you don't feel encouraged to linger. 
It was a little disappointing, but definitely worth seeing if you are in the area. Some of the relics found here have been moved to museums. It is nowhere near as impressive as the catacombs, but worth adding to your 'nice to see' rather than 'must see' list.

reviews.title: Sad to see the neglect
reviews.text:
We visit here often as a family. It costs so little to get in (you have to pay entry into Nozha gardens first and then walk to Antoniadis and pay again there; but its still only about 3 LE in total).

The neglect is almost total. There are no facilities at all inside, no toilets, no drinks kiosks, no snacks. But if you ignore this and go prepared with a picnic it can be an enchanting place. Sitting in the shade of a decaying villa and Palm house surrounded by empty fountain pools; you can have almost the entire gardens entirely to yourself.
Maybe one day this will change. But it probably won't be soon.

reviews.title: Was a pity
reviews.text:
It was a terrible visit. It's a pity to see what had happen to this attraction especially that my husband went there and saw the place back on the 90's and it was so devastating to see what happens to this historical garden and palace. I posted some of the sad picture we took. And following some short info about what Antoniadis was: 

The history of The Villa of Antoniadis goes back to Mohamed Ali era. It is a very famous and important site in Alexandria. A wealthy palace for a once-wealthy group, Villa Antoniadis still remains an exclusive place, it includes statues and a tropical greenhouse. The house itself is surrounded by the Antoniadis Gardens, the Flower Garden, the Zoo and Nozha Gardens. Driving past now on the way to the airport, the tall royal palms and stone pines give just a glimpse of the rare and precious trees which were gathered to fill the garden, and yet it's one of the least visited attractions of Alexandria.
Afterwards, it was used as a guest house to host visiting dignitaries to Egypt, including the King of Belgium, Greece, Italy, the Shah of Iran and Mohamed Reza Pahlavi, who was married to the Egyptian Princess Fawzia, the sister of King Farouk. The Villa also hosted the signing ceremony of the 1936 agreement between Egypt and Britain, which gave Egypt some limited independence, and it held the first meeting of the Egyptian Olympia committee.

reviews.title: A hidden gem!
reviews.text: This must be one of the most underrated museums in Egypt. Not only is the collection excellent, and varied -- ranging from fifteenth century Dutch painting to 20th century Egyptian works -- but the presentation in this recently refurbished building is also decent. The descriptions could be more detailed and complete, but this hardly detracts from the artworks themselves. High points are the small group of paintings by Giambattista Tiepolo (!!!), and an interesting selection of Orientalist works. Eighteenth and ninteteenth century European art is represented mainly through the works of minor artists, which are worth a look nonetheless. On the upper floor, there is a large selection of modern Egyptian art, including works by foreign born artists active in Egypt (e.g. Thalia Flora-Karavia), and several smaller works by Moukhtar. Entrance to the museum is free; this is an absolute must for every art lover.

reviews.title: Besser in das Gebäude nebenan gehen...
reviews.text: Das Kunstmuseum selber hat meiner Meinung nach nicht recht viel zu bieten. Wir haben keinen Eintritt bezahlt (keine Ahnung ob das so regulär war oder ein netter Gefallen weil wir weit und breit die einzigen Gäste waren) und dafür war es ganz okay. Was mich mehr beeindruckt hat, ist das Museum für arabische Kalligraphie, das sich gleich nebenan befindet und dazu gehört. Es handelt sich dabei um ein modernes Museumsgebäude mit einer kleinen aber feinen Sammlung arabischer Schriftstücke. Man sieht sowohl die alten Schreibstile als auch neue experimentelle Kalligraphie. Alles ist schön präsentiert und beschriftet, was in Ägypten ja nicht so selbstverständlich ist... Ich war begeistert!

Overlooking a garden and beaches of the same name, this is a beautiful mosque in an elegant Andalusian style. Truly worth visiting if only to capture the serenity as well as the view from inside the mosque looking outside through the main entrance overlooking the sea!

The Sidi Bishr Mosque is attributed to  Sheikh Bishr ibn Hussein ibn Muhammad ibn Ubayd-Allaah ibn al-Husayn ibn Bishr Elgohary, who came to Alexandria in the late fifth century AH or early sixth century AH with those who came from Morocco and Andalusia scientists in that period . He became well known for his righteousness. He died in 528 Hijri.

reviews.title: In a real village poor part of town
reviews.text:
If you don't have a tour guide with you don't even bother going to this place because you won't be able to distinguish the pieces.  There is  so many different artifacts and they all look similar. 

They charge two EP for parking and don't allow digital cameras inside- cell phones are ok. This is in a  poor part of town so don't be alarmed . The bathrooms are disgusting and are not equipped with toilet paper so bring tissue or tip the lady outside the restroom for some of hers... I highly recommend not using the facilities at all. 
My favorite part was the underground sand built mummies tombs. You take 99 steps down into mummy storage. It's scary cool and even the air is different . Just don't think about earthquakes  while you're under there.

Throughout our time in Egypt we used a tour guide we met at the museum he speaks Italian, English, some Russian and of course Arabic. He has very reasonable prices and knows the history of Egypt very well -he has the answers to everything and we had many questions. From Cairo to Alexandra we gave him 150usd, for several attractions and some mall shopping, this was an all day trip. If you want his information  contact me. 

Prior to meeting him we had two other guides. they were overpriced and taking us to places where they would benefit, pressuring us into purchasing items etc. they were arranged via the hotel. 
My guy is far better!

reviews.title: Interesting dives good company
reviews.text:
Ahmed and his team were lovely fun and safe to dive with. Dives are less than 10m and around 30min or so.
Dives: Cleopatras Palace / lighthouse  
Unfortunately the government has taken out the sphinx and other statues so there is only huge columns and bases left to see there. It was pretty cool if you enjoy that but you need imagination! Otherwise its all covered in barnacles and not much fish.

Pharos Island
Less interesting just rocks and quite a bit of finishing lines. Didn’t see much and the visibility was around 1m.

Two dives in half day but a few words of advice:
1 bring some food for between dives you’ll be out on the boat most of the day.
2 Bring your passport!! I forgot and being Egypt there are a lot of government permissions to go through. Ahmed kindly took me back to my hotel to grab it.
3 be prepared to go with the flow it’s Egypt things take a while just relax and enjoy the day

FYI: They are the only recreational scuba company left in Alexandria as the government closed the others due to unsafe practices.

In 2yrs once Frank Goddios team finish They hope to offer dives to Heraclion site which is quite exciting hopefully the government will keep some of the finds in the sea.

reviews.title: World class art
reviews.text:
This stately villa actually contains three museums: a museum of modern Egyptian art in the basement, the Mahmoud Said museum on the ground floor, and the Adham and Seid Wanly museum on the upper floor (accessible through a separate door to the left of the main entrance).

The first provides an overview of main trends in Egyptian painting since the early 1900s, with some notable works particularly for the first half of the 20th century. The Mahmoud Said museum has a representative collection of his work, including his nudes, but this reviewer finds the landscape paintings (first room right) to be of particular interest. 

The Wanly brothers museum is the real revelation: I was not familiar with the work of either prior to my visit, and was stunned to find their work incredibly interesting, and varied. The early character studies in the first hall are wonderful, as are the late, dreamlike landscapes. In the main hall. 

This is world class art, and it is a pity that the Wanly brothers are not celebrated with greater fanfare as major artists. 

In any other country, there would be books, posters, postcards mugs and umbrellas with reproductions of their work in a museum gift shop. More importantly, there would be classes of school children in the museum, families and young couples. 

Part of the problem is the museum's location, hidden from view in a side street behind the towering San Stefano mall. You are more likely to find it if you look for the delivery entrance of the Fathallah supermarket. 

Entrance is free. This is one of the most important collections in Egypt -- if you like art, don't miss it.

reviews.title: Ein sehr schönes kleines Museum
reviews.text:
Dieses Museum ist wie eine kleinere Ausgabe des Ägyptischen Museums in Kairo.
Es enthält außerrgewöhnliche archeologische Funde aus den letzten fünfzehn Jahren. Es ist auf drei Ebenen aufgeteilt, wobei die älteste Epoche (Pharaonen) ganz unten und die jüngste Epoche (koptisches Christentum/Islam) ganz oben ist.
Im Oktober waren nicht soviele Touristen dort, sodass wir uns das Museum in Ruhe anschauen konnten.
Alle Erklärungen/Erläuterungen gibt es auf arabisch und englisch
Dieses Museum ist auch für gehbehinderte geeignet, da es über eien Aufzug verfügt.
Das Museum ist täglich außer Montags geöffnet von 10:00 bis 18:00 Uhr.

reviews.title: Archaeological sites are not museums .. Enjoy a different experience and travel with your imagination.
reviews.text:
Does it worth the visit? ABSOLUTELY!!
Nevertheless, you need to stretch your imagination and understand that an open archaeological site is not meant to be as fancy as a musuem. 

The tombs are five in number, however I & II are the most important. They belong to the first half of the 3rd century BC. Imagine getting a glimpse of the glam of these days. The tombs are a perfect example of the mélange between Greek and Egyptian decorative motifs during the early Hellenistic era.

The tombs are famous between archaeologists for being cut in the rock, havig rich colourful ceilings and walls, and for their incrustation style (faux-marble); which is a pure Hellenistic invention. It stands for the treatment of plaques to imitate marble wherever it's a rare material, the case in Alexandria and Cyprus. Moreover, tomb II is famous for its colourful scenes of the purification of the deceased. 

The site is rich and it gives a vivid space to stretch imagination and visualise how rich and special these early tombs could have looked back on their day.

Saint Genis who accompanied Napoleon to Egypt (there is a square named after him in Alexandria) described a Necropolis in the western part of the Pharos island with rock-cut catacombs consisting of numerous interconnected chambers with plastered and painted walls and ceilings,then partly filled with sand, which must have been either Anfoushi or Ras El-Tin (In the gardens of the palace of Ras El-Tin and is not opened to the public).

I totally recommend for those who are into getting exposed to a different kind of excursions. May be joining a local guide can lend more hand.

reviews.title: Nice
reviews.text:
A part of a group of monasteries in Wadi Natrun, in the desert west to Delta, this monastery has a history originating in 4th century already. It is dedicated to St Bishuy, who is perhaps unknown in the West, but very popular in Egypt, where quite a few Copts bear this name.

It is located not far from the road between Alexandria and Cairo.

The monastery is surrounded by walls and houses several buildings, not only old ones, but also a big new church for the pilgrims as well as the tomb of a popular pope (patriarch) of the Copts, Shenuda III.

Not only you don't pay to enter, but you can get a free simple meal of bread and broad bean, which is great.

reviews.title: Great History
reviews.text: This is one of my favorite monasteries to visit. I love the history of it and the icons are ancient. The body of Bishoy himself is there along with the last Coptic Pope Shenuda. Also make sure you check out the refectory and you can imagine the monks sitting there and eating together over a thousand years ago.

reviews.title: Monastery with a drawbridge
reviews.text:
Built in 4th cent, it has several churches that have been upgraded several times and renovations are still ongoing. New murals were uncovered recently. 
It's like a fortress, with a drawbridge and a walled off complex within the ramparts. Bishoy's body is still there and the church has an interesting pulpit and doorways. The older parts are still beautiful but modernity is staking claim to the premises. 
The Coptic monks are a friendly lot and have interesting stories of the saints. It's a practicing monastery with over 170 monks and is emerging as a popular tourist destination.

reviews.title: Coptic monastery
reviews.text:
One of the most amazing places in Egypt and the world. An ancient Coptic monastery. 
The spirit of very old churches and the monks in the middle of the dessert.

reviews.title: Fourth century Monestary
reviews.text: If you want to go back in history to the fourth century, then go and visit that monenstary. There you will see Anba Bishoi's cell, where he used to pray all night long to be in the presence of the Lord.

reviews.title: don'

reviews.title: A serenity haven in the Egyptian desert
reviews.text:
Deir Anba Bishoi in Wadi Natrun, not far from Cairo (half way between Cairo and Alexandria), is an image of serenity. It includes a church which holds the body of the Saint Bishoi, founder of the monastery, as well as several other saints; his body is still intact in a "tube-like" coffin, which is taken on procession around the church on July 17th each year.

You can sit in the garden of this monastery, or wander around the new cathedral and watch the resident monks go about their daily chores; you can also enjoy lovely views of the desert from its rooftop. You have to be dressed modestly in such places in Egypt.

Wadi Natrun is located 100 km northwest of Cairo in the Western Desert. The only way to get there is by car or by bus. West Delta Buses leave every hour from the Heliopolis station.

reviews.title: Oldest tombs in Alexandria
reviews.text:
Not as impressive as the catacombs, but reputedly the oldest tombs in Alexandria, The necropolis at Chatby (sometimes written Shatbi or Chatbi) are situated next to the Youth Hostel and across the road from St Marc's College on Port Said Street (near the Corniche, East of Suez Canal Street).
Entry cost 20 EGP for foreigners and my friend and I were the only visitors at the site. The tombs are hewn from sandstone rock which is weathered. Some tombs are above current ground level and others below (partly flooded). There was rubbish/litter/garbage around the site including plastic food wrappers which deterred me from taking photos in some cases. It is not possible to enter any of the underground sections. The site is larger than Mustafa Kamel Necropolis. There is a pleasant garden and shaded seating around. There are sections of columns and parts of statues on display as well, including two headless sphinxes. There are no signs or guidance of any kind for visitors.
Several beautiful items found at this site can be seen in the Alexandria National Museum and for that reason alone I htink this site is worth a visit. As cemeteries and tombs in Alexandria compare, I would rate this above Mustafa Kamel Necropolis (I prefer sites not to be obviously restored) but below the Catacombs. Add them to your "nice to see" rather than "must see" list for historic sites while in Alexandria.

reviews.title: It's terrific for male groups, OK for conservative families, Bad for female groups and females in a bikini and 1 piece
reviews.text:
It was relatively easy to find once we knew it was on the side heading to Alexandria, so we started from Alexandria heading to Cairo, after Alexandria's Gate by about 4 km we took a U turn and we found it on our right.

We found free parking and at the gate we paid 90 Pounds each Including lunch and all Water park games, We also paid a 1 time fee 25 pounds Rent for the big round floater which is used at the big water slide only and all of our group shared this floater many times during the day we would take turns

we arrived at 9:30 am it was pretty empty and enjoyable

there was 5 nice pools avg 1 meter deep, only 1 pool was 1.5 Meters deep which is the max there

There is also a pool that have waves in it which is enjoyable for some time before it gets crowded.

There are 3 slides there for adults and kids older than 15 Years old, there are for small kids but I didn't pay attention to those since we didn't have kids with us.

The 3 slides are as follows:
    1- Big black tube that is fully covered like a pipe has an average drop at it's start and has some turns later, this one you have the option of using a floater in and it is quite more enjoyable with the floater so don't miss out on it. you can go on your back or stomach.
    2- In the middle there is the straight white slide which is very very very fast and straight forward but also quite enjoyable for more than a few times, but this one is operated from 4 pm until the end of the day at 6:30 pm, you can only go on your back in this one.
    3- There is the half pipe white one operated from opening until 4 pm only, this one is enjoyable too for a few times, this one has some turns and you can go on your back or stomach.

until 10:30 am ~ 11 am everything was quite fun and smooth but then people started coming in and it became too crowded and you had to wait for 20 minutes to get on any slide.

after 5:30 pm it was relatively empty again and you can go on slides directly

The reason they switch between those slides i think is because they only have 2 water compressor pumps which is needed to operate the slides so at 4 pm they switch.

at 3 pm there is a break until 4 pm.

The quality of people there makes it hard for females to enjoy this attraction specially if they are attractive and/or wearing non conservative swim suite.

So if you have a family with small kids or you are a group of guys you will have amazing fun, if you a group of guys and girls / family of guys and girls then you will also have fun but make sure no bikinis or one piece swimsuits only full body swim suites.

P.S. like any water parks or pools you can only go into the water if you are wearing swim suites, NO COTTON NO JEANS!

I hope this is helpful for others, have a great time on your next trip

reviews.title: Fascinating detour on the road back to Cairo
reviews.text:
As other people have outlined this is not near anywhere on the rod between Alexandria and Cairo. But if you get the opportunity it is certainly worth a visit - would only delay your journey by 90 minutes or so.
We were shown round by one of the residents who provided an excellent informative soundtrack to the history and also present day life in the monastery. He answered all questions he could and clearly enjoyed his time with his audience.
A fascinating and enjoyable detour

reviews.title: Most peaceful
reviews.text: This has to be one of the most peaceful places on earth. Definitely off the beaten track on the way from El Alamein to Cairo, it’s really worth seeking out. The guided tour highlights parts of the monastery which date back to the 7th Century and details the daily lives of the Coptic monks together with the workings of the monastery and its farm. I didn’t think we’d spend much time here but none of us wanted to rush away.

reviews.title: Next time
reviews.text: We made it all the way to the monastery gates. Unfortunately we could not get in, as for the last two days, the monastery was hosting religious dignitaries for a feast and one needed an invitation to enter. As such, if you plan to visit, consider calling ahead.

reviews.title: Large Coptic monastery
reviews.text:
This large monastery includes many relics relating to Saint Macarius and also John the Baptist.
An old tamarind tree is supposed to date back to the 4th century.
Our guiding monk was friendly and showed us a sample of the ancient monk's cells.

reviews.title: St. John Baptists & Prophet Elisha's burial Place
reviews.text:
The Monastery was about to abandoned in the late 60s with only 7 very old monks whose age was between 105 - 80 years old until the revival of the Monastery took place in 1969 by Pope Cyril VI's decision to send 12 pioneering monks to revive it's Spiritual heritage and Architecture.
In 1977 the burial place of St. John the Baptist - considered the greatest man born by the biblical statement of Jesus Christ - after years of elaborate studies to confirm the exactitude of the discovery.

Unlike Orthodox doctrine dedicating the Northern Altar to Virgin Mary when the Central Altar is not dedicated to her, this church had the Central Altar dedicated to Pope Benjamin (38th Pope of Alexandria) and the Northern Altar to St. John the baptist. Furthermore the generation-to-generation delivered heritage included stopping in the corner and providing incenses similarly to when there is a body of a great Saint.
After removing sand as high as 4-5 feet (120-150 cms) in the church, a catacomb was found with 2 bodies. Studying centuries old manuscripts, they were confirmed to be the bodies of Old Testament Prophet Elisha & St. John the baptist.

reviews.title: BIG and interesting
reviews.text: This is a huge, working monastery. Make sure you guide is good, call ahead to get the language you want to get so he is ready for you.

reviews.title: Ancient coptic monastery
reviews.text: This monastery is one of the 4 ancient coptic monasteries of Wadi Al Natrun and it is the nearest to Cairo (around km 90).  If possible, visit on week days and not on high feasts to avoid crowds. Make sure not to attempt a visit during lent or the weeks before Christmas, as it will be closed. Hopefully you will be showed around by one of the fathers, you will see some remarkable murals and other witnesses of old coptic monasticism. by the way, the monastery has a farm and gardens attached, producing fruit and wonderful cheese.

Από τα τέσσερα κόπτικα μοναστήρια της περιοχής αυτό είναι το πλέον απόκοσμο και επιβλητικό. ϊσως γιατί μόλις μπήκαμε, ήρθε ένας μοναχός επιφορτισμένος με την ξενάγηση και με αξαιρετικά αγγλικά μας ξενάγησε στο χώρο. πετύχαμε μάλιστα και εξορκισμο. reviews.title: Not open
reviews.text: We were not allowed to enter. It’s quite annoying when it has been restored. For whom was it restored then?

reviews.title: Do NOT TAKE PHOTOS
reviews.text: I tried to visit this synagogue which had no signage at all on the gate which was unlocked. A soon as we snapped a photo through the open gate, 3 men started screaming at us in Arabic. Another came through the gate immediately. They took our phone away even though we explained we would delete the photo. The four of them kept our phone for about five minutes scrolling through the camera roll to see if we had taken more photos, the entire time shouting angrily at us.  We had an Arabic speaker with us who was trying to explain it was one photo and we deleted it. Very scary. Not sure if they were police or guards but do not approach the gate to take photos.

reviews.title: Not Open to Egyptians
reviews.text: It seems truly wonderful, but I only got a chance to see it from he outside. I wasn't allowed inside because I held no foreign passport. And the staff were condescending and rude.

reviews.title: Lost cosmopolitan Alexandria
reviews.text: A must on any walking tour of the this fabulous city of bitter-sweet memories. Expect the synagogue to be closed and guarded.

reviews.title: Closed all the time
reviews.text: For security reasons the authorities are closing it all the time after the immigration of the jews in the 1950s , it is in the heart of historical Alexandria,a very important place to visit, even if you cant get inside, you can see the outer facades

reviews.title: تعليقى عن الاسكندرية لن يكون محايد
reviews.text: للاسف لن يكون هذا التعليق محايد فان قسوت فذلك لحبى وعشقى للاسكندرية ولكن لن اذكر الا الحقيقة للاسف الكورنبش اصبح فى حالة سيئة جدا كنت اعشق المشى على الكورنيش والتمتع بالمنظر الجميل ولكن الان لا تستطيع ان تمشى بحرية تامة حتى الباعة الجائلين غير منظمين وبشكل عشوائى - محمد احمد بتاع الفول بعد ان تم بيعة اصبحت الخدمة والجودة دون المستوى - مطعم نصار بموقعة الجميل تخلى عن مكانة ورونقة - لم يبقى فى محطة الرمل الا البن البرازيلى الذى حولة طلبة المدارس الى سويقة ولكنة مازال بة بعض الامل - تريانون الجميل ولكن دخول الشيشة سيفسد القاعدة الجميلة حديقة انطونيادس حدث ولا حرج عن الاهمال واللامبالة لو كانت هذة الحديقة فى اى مكان اخر لحولوها الى كنز من الذهب - متحف المجوهرات الملكية جميل جدا ومنظم ومازال بة عبق التاريخ وبالمناسبة الدخول لة للمسنين فوق 60 عام مجانا مازالت قرية بلبع سيدى بشر رقم واحد فى الجودة والاسعار الفنادق تكلمت عنها بالتفصيل نادى المهندسين اصبح سوق بلدى لا يوجد بة اى ذوق او حس هندسى المخرج حديقة المنتزة واصبح الدخول لها ب25 جنية للفرد خلاف رسم دخول السيارة

reviews.title: 能看到建築設計特徵仍然會很有趣
reviews.text: 亞歷山大港最古老的建築之一。被認為是直到50年代的猶太禮拜堂。它們離開埃及後，這個地方就被關閉。位於歷史悠久的亞歷山大市中心，是一個非常重要的參觀地點。因此，能看到建築設計特徵仍然會很有趣。許多士兵圍著並守衛著這座建築。

reviews.title: جيد
reviews.text: اذا كان لديك وقت من الممكن زيارة هذا المعبد لانه عادي لا يوجد به الشي الكثير حتى تكتشفه في هذا المعبد

reviews.title: تصميم مميز ونادر في مصر
reviews.text: معبد الياهو هو المعبد اليهودي بالاسكندريه وبطبيعة الحال وبعد هجرة اليهود في الستينات ولم يعد يتواجد يهود بمصر الا قلة قليله ولهذا فالمعبد مغلق اغلب الوقت الا في المناسبات القليلة الدينية اليهودية ولكنه يتميز بتصميم مميز وزخارف وتاريخ شيق انصح بزيارتة اذا استطعت

reviews.title: المعبد اليهودى بالاسكندريه
reviews.text: كنت وانا صغير اذهب الى مدينة الاسكندريه للفسحه وللشوبينج وكنت دائما لكى اذهب الى محطة الرمل اسير فى شارع النبى دانيال وهوا شارع مشهور جدا وكنت بمر بمبنى ضخم على يمينى ومحاط ببوابه كبيره وسور حديدى كبير وعليه حراسه كثيره وعندما سالت عن هذا المبنى عرفت انه المعبد اليهودى وهوا مغلق دائما الا فى مناسبات قليله لوصول افواج سياحيه له من اليهود

description: Enjoy this once in a lifetime experience that has you discovering the exotic underwater world of the Red Sea. Board your coach at the pier for the short drive to Sharks Bay where your motorboat awaits at Hyatt Regency resort. Once you have boarded, you'll set off on a northern course toward an area of the Bay known for its wonderful snorkeling opportunities.Arriving at one of the premier snorkeling areas, you can either relax on board the boat or enter the warm, crystalline waters where you can swim and snorkel amongst the colorful fish and beautiful coral formations. A qualified instructor accompanies you during your excursion to provide assistance and offer information about the region's marine life as well as direct the boat to the best snorkeling spots. Bottled water and soft drinks are available on board for your refreshment.After approximately 2 hours enjoying the enchanting marine environment of the Red Sea, you'll head back to Sharks Bay where you'll be transferred back to the ship.
